entry.title: Re: RFQ
entry.content:
Thank you for your details, I need one more information,

In the SAP Public Cloud, a Supplier Quotation cannot be submitted unless a price is entered for all items in the RFQ. For example, consider an RFQ containing three materials:

Supplier 1 provides prices for only the first two items.

Supplier 2 provides prices for all three items.

In this case, Supplier 1 offers the best price for the first two items, while Supplier 2‚Äôs price is to be considered for the third item. The requirement is to enable the system to award individual line items from different supplier quotations ‚Äî i.e., to award the first two items to Supplier 1 and the third item to Supplier 2 ‚Äî even if a supplier has not quoted for all items in the RFQ. Currently, since the system does not allow submission of a quotation without prices for all RFQ items, this functionality cannot be achieved directly. We need a solution or configuration that allows partial quotation submission or item-level award processing in Supplier Quotations.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4HANA public cloud - clearing of bank subaccounts
entry.content:
Hello @panagiotism 

Here are some more information.

The following references will provide you with more details.

Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing, Automatic Payments, Automatic Clearing

Schedule General Ledger Jobs, Clear Open Items - Automatic Clearing

To summarise, public cloud edition enables automatic clearing through the Schedule General Ledger Jobs app strictly according to matching criteria defined in the Automatic Clearing Rules (SSCUI 102639).

Even though your open items belong to the same G/L account, the system will only clear them automatically if the key fields between the debit and credit line items match well.

When you used the Manage Automatic Payments app, the system credited the bank subaccount with certain attributes (e.g., reference, assignment, document type text, clearing date). When you imported the bank statement, it created a debit on the same account but with potentially different reference values, which prevents matching automatic clearing.

Finally, the assignment or document type did not match, hence why the automatic clearing job did not connect the two open times. Adjust your automatic Clearing Rules and ensure both posting populate the same Assignment field. After you aligned them, rerun the job and your items will clear automatically.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unable to Modify Backup Storage & Network Data Transfer Parameters During HANA DB Instance Creation
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

While creating a HANA DB instance in our SAP environment, we noticed that the backup storage and network data transfer parameters are being populated automatically. There doesn‚Äôt seem to be any option to modify or deselect these during instance creation.

However, in the SAP Discovery Center Estimator, these parameters can be adjusted, and the cost per capacity unit can vary accordingly.

Could someone please clarify:

  • Why are these parameters fixed during the actual HANA instance creation even though they are configurable in the estimator?
  • Is there any way (or specific service plan/region restriction) that allows modification of these parameters before provisioning?

Would like to validate if this behavior is by design or if there are configuration options we might be missing.

Thanks in advance for your insights.

entry.title: Incorrect Forecast Consumption in LZM Scheduling Agreement
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

we are facing an issue with forecast consumption in Scheduling Agreements (type LZM ‚Äì ‚ÄúScheduling agreement with delivery order‚Äù) and would appreciate any best-practice guidance from others who have handled similar setups.

 

Current Process

Customers first send a DELINS, which creates forecast schedule lines in the scheduling agreement and corresponding entries in VBBE, visible in MD04 as planned requirements.

When a DELORD (delivery order) is received, SAP creates delivery Order schedule lines with the ordered quantities.
In MD04, these quantities automatically consume the forecast. SAP simply reduces available forecast quantities top-down across the next open forecast buckets until the ordered quantity is reached.
The consumed forecasts disappear from VBBE, although the schedule lines remain stored in VBEP.

This setup works fine as long as the next DELINS still includes all open forecast periods, allowing SAP to consume against the same buckets.

 

The Issue

Some customers send new DELINS messages that only contain future forecast periods, removing all earlier forecasts once a DELORD has been sent.

Example:

  • Initial DELINS (weeks 41‚Äì52): 50 pcs per week
  • Then DELORD in week 42: 100 pcs (covers weeks 41‚Äì42) ‚Üí consumes those 100 pcs of forecast
  • Next DELINS: starts from week 43 only (weeks 41‚Äì42 are no longer included)

Since SAP only sees forecasts from week 43 onward, it continues to consume the open delivery order quantities against the remaining future forecasts.
This causes the forecast consumption to shift forward, and MD04 shows incorrect demand.

 

Observed Patterns

Customer type

DELINS behavior

Result in SAP

Type A

Sends DELINS including all still-open forecasts (even if goods not yet received)

Works fine ‚Äì forecasts consumed correctly

Type B

Sends DELINS only for future periods (removes previous ones after DELORD)

Not working ‚Äì delivery quantities consume future forecasts

 

What I‚Äôm Looking For

Has anyone found a best-practice approach to handle this?
We would like to:

  • keep forecasts visible in VBBE / MD04,
  • but disable consumption for customers who already clean up their forecasts on their side.

Thanks a lot for any input or shared experience!

entry.title: SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
New Transactional Use Cases for Approvals and Navigational Use Cases for AI Copilot Joule in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP-2288)

This feature adds navigational use cases for viewing supplier data and performing common supplier management activities, and transactional use cases for approvals, in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance with AI copilot Joule. Users can get assistance from Joule for viewing supplier profiles, creating supplier request and modular questionnaire projects, finding out approval status for projects where they're an approver, and finding the projects that are pending their approval.

 
This feature adds the following capabilities in Joule for supplier management:

Use Case Type

Use Case

Description

Example

Transactional

Tasks still pending approval

Displays a list of tasks pending approval by the current user, with options for approving or denying the tasks in Joule. Results include matching tasks in all project types. There's currently no way to filter the list by project type.

Tasks in some supplier management projects also support a Request Additional Info option. You must navigate to the task details page if you want to use this option rather than approving or denying the task.

Show me tasks pending approval

Transactional

Check approval status

Displays the approval status and currently active approvers of the specified task. You must include the task's ID in the question

Check approval status for task TSK1234567

Navigational

View a supplier's profile

Displays the matching supplier or suppliers. Choose Open in App to view the supplier's profile. To find suppliers by ID, you must include the supplier's SM vendor ID in the question.

Show me the profile for supplier 12345678

Show me the profile for supplier ABC

Navigational

Create a supplier request

Displays a Create supplier request in app quick link that opens the supplier request form or questionnaire configured for your site, if you have permission to create supplier requests. The link opens either the standard supplier request or the Dun & Bradstreet-integrated supplier request, depending on which one your organization uses.

Take me to the page for creating a supplier request

Navigational

Send modular questionnaires to suppliers

Displays a Send modular questionnaires in app quick link that opens the first page in the workflow for inviting suppliers to standalone modular questionnaires, if you have permission to create modular questionnaire projects.

Take me to the page for creating a modular questionnaire

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Exclude System Generated Versions during ERP sync Internal and External Registrations (SLP-2310)

This feature ensures a new questionnaire version is only created if ERP sync changes the vendor mapped questions of the current active version, preventing unnecessary versions and maintaining clarity in version tracking in registration questionnaire only. (This feature is applicable only to supplier registration.)

View implementation details and more here.

 

New User Research Panel Link in the User Feedback Survey (SLP-2333)

When users complete the feedback survey, they now see a new user research panel link on the thank you page. The link allows users to sign up for the SAP User Research Panel, where they can engage with SAP and provide product feedback.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Changes to the User Interface

After a user submits a completed feedback survey, the thank you page now includes a SAP User Research Panel link. Choosing the link opens a sign-up form for the panel.

View implementation details and more here.

 

AI Copilot Joule in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk (SRISK-1848)

Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, is now available in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk. Joule uses a conversational interface to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify intent, perform actions, and provide insights. Using generative AI, it can execute tasks, deliver tailored responses, and summarize information effectively.

View implementation details and more here.

 

New Country/Region Risk Provider (SRISK-1833)

A new default country/region risk provider, Moody‚Äôs Analytics, is available to include up to date country/region risk information in your risk exposure. 

Including the country/region risk as a contributing factor to risk exposure for suppliers allows organizations to make more informed business decisions. The country/region risk exposure is displayed on the SAP Ariba Supplier Risk dashboard and in the supplier 360¬∞ profile.

Currently, SAP Ariba Supplier Risk uses country risk score data from the World Economic Forum (WEF) as the default source of information. With this enhancement, Moody‚Äôs Analytics becomes the default source of country risk score data.

Moody‚Äôs Analytics Country/Region Risk Index compares investment risk across 191 countries, provides a single country risk score, is updated quarterly, and aggregates threats along six risk dimensions:

  1. Macroeconomic risk

  2. Business risk

  3. Financial risk

  4. Social risk

  5. Political risk

  6. Security risk

Changes to the User Interface

  • On the SAP Ariba Supplier Risk dashboard, the Country/Region score (WEF) column in the Your Suppliers section is now changed to Country/Region score (Moody's).

  • On the supplier profile page, the Risk Exposure tab on the Risk menu displays Moody's risk categories.

  • Any other text or link that references the World Economic Forum (WEF) is now replaced with Moody's.

View implementation details and more here.

 
 

SAP Spend Control Tower - Feature highlights

Data Quality Analytics Dashboards (ARBARE-157)

This feature enables you to analyze the accuracy, completeness, and consistency of spend data loaded from source systems into SAP Spend Control Tower in the Data Quality dashboard. 
Examples of the User Interface:
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
View implementation details and more here.
 

Manage Spend Taxonomy Enhancements (ARBTS-215)

This feature includes enhancements that enable you to expand your custom taxonomy by adding new categories, moving categories, and mapping additional UNSPSC codes.
 
You can now add a new custom category to support new products, map it to a unique UNSPSC level 4 code, and validate changes via SAP Spend Control Tower to prevent duplicates. Additionally, you can move custom taxonomy categories, along with their subtrees, to a new parent, which updates roll-ups for display and dashboards without altering item-level classifications or UNSPSC mappings. Unused UNSPSC codes can also be added to any custom leaf node to extend the taxonomy.
 

Changes to the User Interface

The Spend Taxonomy tab on the custom taxonomy page includes the following new buttons:

  • Add Categories

  • Add UNSPSC Mappings

  • Move To

 
 
 
 
 
View implementation details and more here.
 

Multi-Field Search for Invoice Item Categorization (ARBTS-95)

This feature enables you to evaluate and confirm proper invoice line item categorization using the new Invoice Items View on the Review Invoice Items Categorization page, which streamlines identifying items for review and applying consistent categorization.

The Invoice Items View lists aggregated invoice items and provides a multi-functional search to help you find items that need review. You can also save search criteria and apply a saved search to filter invoice items.

Review Invoice Items Categorization - Grouped View 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

View implementation details and more here.

 

Spend Analysis Benchmarks ‚Äî Company vs Industry Performance (ANALYSIS-1324)

This feature enables you to view a comparative analysis of year-to-date company spend values and the industry averages along with the deviations for various spend categories in the Spend Analysis Benchmarks ‚Äî Company vs Industry Performance dashboard.

SAP Spend Control Tower uses anonymized historical data to develop benchmarks for supplier spend and category spend. This data is used to create a benchmark report.

The Spend Analysis Benchmarks ‚Äî Company vs Industry Performance dashboard provides insights into your company‚Äôs spend performance. It enables you to:

  • Compare spend performance across your enterprise, for example by company code or location, against the average and best performer within your company.

  • Compare your overall enterprise spend performance to industry peers, including the industry average and top performers in each area.

 

 

 

View implementation details and more here.

 

Stay connected with your community for more insights and updates:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • What‚Äôs New

entry.title: Configuring Attachment Fields in Additional Data Collection visible in Onboarding Documents
entry.content:
Article written together with @Pratyusha_Kumar 

 

This article explains how attachments uploaded by the new joiners during Additional Data Collection step can be made visible under Onboarding dashboard, along with documents generated through Onboarding custom tasks and E-signed policy forms.

Previously, the attachments uploaded by new joiners were visible only under Manage Documents.

Step 1: Configure the Custom MDF Object for Additional Data collection step for capturing attachments from new onboards.

  1. Create the MDF object with required attachment fields. For Additional Data Collection, set externalCode as Auto Number for Data Type and include the field cust_userConfig as Generic Object with ONB2DataCollectionUserConfig on Valid Values Source.

Sample Taken from Demo System.

 

Screenshot 2(cust_userConfig) field details.

 

 

 

  1. Add the cust_subjectUser field - Configure this field as ‚ÄúUser‚Äù Data type with ‚ÄúRead Only‚Äù visibility. This field is mandatory for the attachment configuration to work properly.

 

  1. Please do also make sure the MDF version History to ‚ÄúComplete History‚Äù.

 

 

 

  1. Create an ‚ÄúOnSave‚Äù business rule in the Save rules section:
    • Add rule name, rule ID, and start date
    • Select your custom MDF as the Base Object
    • Set Purpose to "Evaluate"
    • Configure rule as "Always True"
    • In the Then section, set subjectUser equal to the custom MDF userConfig.subjectUser.

Please see the screenshot below. Do not forget to also add the External User Visibility rule under Initiate section for all custom MDFs setup as Secured=Yes.

 

Step 2: Configure the Attachment Field Configuration

  1. Navigate to Admin Center > Manage Data and create new Attachment Field Configuration
  2. Configure the following settings:
    • Object Type: Select your custom object used in Additional data collection step
    • Attachment Field: Select the specific attachment field
    • Attachment Category: Select "Custom New Hire"
    • Entity ID: Select ‚Äúcust_subjectUser‚Äù the new field you have added to the custom Object.
    • Module: Select "ONBOARDING"
  3. (Important)- Repeat for each attachment field of the MDF object- Create separate configurations for each attachment field for your custom MDF.

 

Prerequisites and Additional Configuration

Required Prerequisites

  • Configure Additional Data Collection with customized data collection object instance
  • Create the custom field cust_subjectUser as described above
  • Create and configure the OnSave business rule for read audit and change audit
  • Ensure proper role-based permissions (RBP) are configured

Complete the Setup

After configuring the attachment fields, complete the following:

  • Create the UI for Additional Data collection
  • Add the new UI to Manage Data configuration
  • Configure Onboarding Data collection user configuration association (additional information can be found here)- must be present
  • Review business rules for triggering Additional Data collection

 

Results and Access

Once properly configured, attachments uploaded by new joiners during Additional Data Collection will be visible to Onboarding Coordinators or Managers (depending on customer requirements) under:

Onboarding Dashboard > New Hire Details > Actions > Onboarding Documents > Download

This provides a centralized repository for all candidate onboarding documents alongside documents generated through Onboarding and Compliance document workflows.

 

 

Details of Documents attached.

 

Common Questions:

Q: After this configuration completed, does the already uploaded documents come up in Onboarding dashboard new hire records?

Ans: No It wont, you have to restart the onboarding Process.

Q: Do we have to do it for each MDF object and each field within the MDF object?

Ans: Yes, for those mdf for whom you need the documents to be seen in Onboarding dashboards the guideline above has to be followed the other alternative way is via manage documents tool

Q: Does the document no longer stored in Manage documents after above configurations is applied?

Ans: Yes moving forward the documents will reflect both in onboarding dashboard and manage documents.

Q: What will be the naming convention of Files when displayed in Onboarding dashboard?

Ans: The name of the file displayed with the same name the new hire uploaded into the onboarding portal, hence it‚Äôs requested to put instruction in additional data collection step for any naming convention you want the new hire to upload with.

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI latest patch
entry.content:
@sapreinhart77 We just rolled back to PL13 it works fine there, our users could not tolerate the work around.

PL15 is ready was released some days ago:

SAP GUI for Windows 8.00 patch
15EXE193913 KB24.10.202524.10.2025 

Note 3616716.

Symptom

In the SAP GUI for Windows TextEdit Control, the entered text is automatically deleted when the control loses focus. This issue occurs only with the Belize and newer themes. It was introduced in SAP GUI version 800, Patch 14 with SAP Note 3616716.

Other Terms

SAP GUI for Windows; text edit;belize;empty;text;delete;tab;focus;loss;not save;cannot save;

Reason and Prerequisites

Program error

Solution

The issue described above is fixed by an SAP GUI for Windows patch. Section "SP Patch Level" lists the patch that contains the respective correction per affected release. Install this patch or a newer one to obtain a correction for the issue (SAP GUI patches are always cumulative). If section "SP Patch Level" is not available or the information on the patchlevels is missing, this means that this information has not been determined, yet. In this case, please re-check this SAP Note at a later point of time.

Expected delivery dates of SAP GUI for Windows patches

If the patch, which contains the correction from this SAP Note is not yet delivered, you can check SAP Note 1053737 for the expected delivery date. You can also subscribe to that SAP Note to get informed in case of updates. How to subscribe to an SAP Note is explained in SAP Knowledge Base Article 2171560.

Downloading SAP GUI patches

All SAP GUI patches are available on SAP Support Portal. Detailed information about the location of the patches can be taken from SAP Note 563161.
Please take into account that as of SAP GUI for Windows 8.00 there are two kinds of patches for core SAP GUI: A 32bit patch and a 64bit patch. You need to download the appropriate version matching your installation (else the attempt to update will be refused by the installation program).

entry.title: Generate JWT (JSON Web Token) with RSA SHA256 in SAP ABAP for Secure API Integrations
entry.content:
Introduction

In modern API integrations, security is critical. JWT (JSON Web Token) with RSA SHA256 is widely used for secure authentication. While most implementations rely on SAP CPI, this blog demonstrates how to generate JWT directly in SAP ABAP for secure banking integrations.

Why JWT + RSA SHA256?

  • Token-based authentication for APIs.
  • Asymmetric encryption ensures high security.
  • Ideal for banking and sensitive data exchange.

What is JWT?

JWT stands for json web token, used for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.

It consists of three parts:

  • Header ‚Üí Specifies algorithm and token type
  • Payload ‚Üí Contains claims (data like issuer, audience, expiration)
  • Signature ‚Üí Verifies integrity and authenticity

What is RSA SHA256?

RSA SHA256 is a cryptographic algorithm that combines:

  • RSA ‚Üí Asymmetric encryption using a public/private key pair
  • SHA256 ‚Üí Secure hashing algorithm for creating a unique message digest

Together, they ensure that the JWT signature is tamper-proof and can only be verified by the corresponding public key.

Challenges in SAP ABAP

  1. No Standard JWT Library in ABAP
  2. RSA SHA256 Signing
  3. Key Management

Step-by-Step Implementation

Step 1: Generate RSA Key Pair and Import into STRUST

  • Use OpenSSL or similar tool to generate a public/private key pair.
  • Import the private key into a custom PSE (e.g., JWT_PK) in STRUST.
  • Upload required certificates (root, intermediate, signed).

Step 2: Create JWT Header and Payload in ABAP

  • JWT consists of Header, Payload and Signature.
  • Header
{
"alg":"RS256",
"typ":"JWT"
}
  • Payload
{
     "iss":        "Test-Bank",
     "jti":        "b98f361e",
     "aud":        "Banking",
     "iat":        lv_iat,
     "exp":        lv_exp,
     "sub":        "Act",
     "payload":    {
                      "clientReferenceId": "Test"
                      }
                      }‚Äã

 Step 3: Base64URL Encode Header and Payload

  • Use /UI2/CL_JSON for JSON serialization.
  • Use CL_HTTP_UTILITY=>ENCODE_BASE64 for encoding, then replace + and / with - and _ for Base64URL.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BASE64_ENCODE_STR'
    EXPORTING
      input  = lv_header_x
    IMPORTING
      output = lv_header_b64.

  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BASE64_ENCODE_STR'
    EXPORTING
      input  = lv_payload_x
    IMPORTING
      output = lv_payload_b64.

  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '+' IN lv_header_b64 WITH '-'.
  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '/' IN lv_header_b64 WITH '_'.
  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '=' IN lv_header_b64 WITH ''.

  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '+' IN lv_payload_b64 WITH '-'.
  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '/' IN lv_payload_b64 WITH '_'.
  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '=' IN lv_payload_b64 WITH ''.

  lv_jwt_input = |{ lv_header_b64 }.{ lv_payload_b64 }|.‚Äã

Step 4: Sign Using RSA SHA256

Since ABAP does not have a direct JWT signing method, we use SAP Secure Store and Forward (SSF) Kernel function module SSFW_KRN_SIGN with the private key stored in STRUST.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Fetch PSE details
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM ssf_pse_h INTO (ls_ssf_pse)
  WHERE filename EQ 'SAPJWT_PK100.pse'.  "PSE filename stored in strust

ls_signer-id      = ls_ssf_pse-id.
ls_signer-profile = ls_ssf_pse-filename.
APPEND ls_signer TO lt_signer.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Sign header.payload using RSA SHA256
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
CALL FUNCTION 'SSFW_KRN_SIGN'
  EXPORTING
    str_format       = 'PKCS1-V1.5'
    str_hashalg      = 'SHA256'
    str_chainfmt     = 'X509v3'
    ostr_input_data  = lv_jwt_input_x
  IMPORTING
    ostr_signed_data = lv_signature_x
    str_signer_name  = lv_signer_name
    ostr_chain_data  = lv_chain_data
    crc              = lv_crc
  TABLES
    signer           = lt_signer
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS           = 1.

IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  WRITE: / 'Error signing JWT.'.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Base64URL encode the signature
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BASE64_ENCODE_STR'
  EXPORTING
    input  = lv_signature_x
  IMPORTING
    output = lv_signature_b64.

REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '+' IN lv_signature_b64 WITH '-'.
REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '/' IN lv_signature_b64 WITH '_'.
REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '=' IN lv_signature_b64 WITH ''.

Step 5: Combine Header.Payload.Signature

  • Final JWT format:
Base64URL(header) + '.' + Base64URL(payload) + '.' + Base64URL(signature)

Conclusion

Generating JWT with RSA SHA256 in SAP ABAP is not straightforward because ABAP lacks native JWT libraries. However, by leveraging STRUST for key management and the SSFW_KRN_SIGN function for RSA signing, you can implement secure API authentication directly in SAP. This approach is ideal for banking and other high-security integrations, ensuring data integrity and compliance without relying on external tools.

entry.title: Joule is Now Integrated into SAP Build Work Zone - Advanced Edition
entry.content:
Exciting News! Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI assistant, is now integrated into SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone making Joule available across all SAP Build Work Zone editions including SAP Build Work Zone standard edition, SAP Start, and SAP Mobile Start. This marks a significant step in empowering users to work faster and smarter, with seamless access to insights and information at their fingertips.

What is Joule? 

Joule is SAP‚Äôs cutting-edge generative AI assistant, designed to bring intelligence and efficiency to every aspect of work.  Leveraging its generative AI capabilities, Joule aims to understand your requests, retrieve information, and complete your tasks in a conversational way. You can describe the current task to Joule, who can help automate tasks or take you to places where you can find desired data. By using Joule, you can easily interact with the system and increase your productivity. Learn more about Joule here.

Now Available : Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition

With our latest release, Joule is now integrated into SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. The artificial intelligence copilot tool  enables users to simply ask a question or present a problem and receive replies from connected SAP systems.

Joule when used within SAP Build Work Zone, extrapolates productivity by providing step-by-step guidance within the site helping you navigate and manage content. Imagine you're trying to track the status of a purchase order. Instead of navigating through multiple screens, you simply ask Joule, ‚ÄúHas my purchase order been approved?‚Äù. Joule instantly provides the status and key details directly within its window in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

How to Get Started with the Integration

  • Before completing the Joule onboarding tasks, you'll need to ensure that you've met the required prerequisites for both SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition and for Joule. For a list of these prerequisites, please refer to: Prerequisites.
  • You have ensured that the SAP Systems where you want to integrate Joule, are registered in the System Landscape page in the SAP BTP cockpit.
  • The SAP Solutions which are registered as Systems are visible in the Booster for selection. For more information, see Maintaining Unified Customer Landscape.
  • You must Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant and Configure User Attributes for Joule from the Identity Directory.
  • The Joule booster has to be run. For more information, see Run the Joule Booster.

Note : When running the Joule booster or formation, choose integration with only a single SAP Build Work Zone edition. Choosing both standard and advanced editions will cause the integration to fail.

Integrating Joule into your SAP Build Work Zone is straightforward. After successfully running the Joule booster and completing the integration between SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition and Joule, a new setting becomes available in the Site Setting screen of your site.

Finally, as an administrator, navigate to the Site Settings screen and enable the Joule option under the Services section. Once enabled, the Joule icon will appear in the header of your runtime site, giving users instant access to the AI-powered assistant for enhanced productivity and elevated outcomes across business.

What‚Äôs Next?

Joule integration has transformed how we approach day to day activities  within SAP Build . With SAP TechEd 2025 fast approaching, we are excited to showcase you our capabilities in our on-site and virtual sessions . This is just the beginning , stay tuned for more AI related latest updates as we bring further innovation to your SAP Build experience.

entry.title: Manage AI DAR in SAP MDG using Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, let us understand how to leverage SAP Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM) to manage Generative AI and AI business services in the SAP MDG. This blog mainly focuses on how to use one of the AI Business Services i.e. Data Attribute Recommendation (DAR) in MDG via ISLM.

MDG Scenario

Just taken a simple scenario to showcase of Intelligent Scenario (ISLM) in MDG to derive material Group [MATKL] in MDG change request (CR) based on material type [MTART]. DAR is used to predict the material group from a trained machine learning model by accepting the material type as input from MDG CR using ISLM.

Implementation

1. BTP

First of all, The BTP account is needed to create instance on the AI business service DAR to have machine learning model. If you do not have a BTP account, please refer this link to create a BTP trial account Get an Account on SAP BTP Trial | SAP Tutorials.

you can find the Data Attribute Recommendation (DAR) in the service marketplace to create an instance.

After the instance created for DAR, the service key is to be created which would help to connect to this DAR from MDG via ISLM.

 

Please take a note of this service key which will be used in ISLM connection mapping later.

To simplify the above setup, please refer the below link to use booster to setup the DAR.

Use Trial to Set Up Account for Data Attribute Recommendation and Download Postman Sample Files | SAP Tutorials

Please refer the below links to use postman to create schema and dataset which will be used in prediction class.

Install Postman REST Client | SAP Tutorials

Use Data Attribute Recommendation to Train a Machine Learning Model | SAP Tutorials

 

2. Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM) in MDG System

  • ISLM is part of the ABAP Platform offered as core functionality in ABAP stack. 
  • ISLM Framework is developed in SAP BASIS Component from ABAP Platform 2020 delivery with SAP BASIS  755 / 7.8x onwards.
  • ISLM facilitates and helps to consume the Machine learning scenarios with an ABAP based Business Application seamlessly
  • ISLM helps to integrate AI and AI Business services into MDG system (S/4HANA).
  • ISLM offers an end-to-end framework to manage both pre-delivered and custom AI scenarios in SAP S/4HANA.

In this example, would like to walk through custom AI-DAR scenario through ISLM.

The below configuration is to be completed in MDG system to enable ISLM related applications.

  • Setting up the OData Services
  • Setting up the bgRFC Queue
  • Configuring Business Roles for the Backend
  • Configuring Business Roles for the Frontend

Please make sure that role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST is assigned to the user which is required to access the below Intelligent Scenario Apps. 

Click on Intelligent Scenarios App to create an intelligent scenario to consume AI business service DAR.

As you may aware, SAP ISLM provides two options as Embedded and Side-by-Side. In this example, would like to cover side-by-side scenario. So, click on create Button to initiate a side-by-side scenario creation.

Enter Scenario Name, Description and Type as Data Attribute Recommendation.

Click on Checkbox Data Management to manage the data provision to ML model from CDS view in MDG system.

It is recommended to use $TMP local package in ISLM until the Intelligent scenario is developed and tested thoroughly. After finalization, create the application package specific intelligent scenario. ISLM creates 'Intelligent Scenario' as an ABAP Object (Transportable / added to a TR based on catalog/package).

Create a prediction class with interface IF_ISLM_INTS_SBS_DAR which will be assigned in the intelligent scenario.

click on Add model after entered data management checkbox, package and prediction class.

Create a CDS view (Z_I_MATDAR) with fields material number [MATNR], material type [MTART] and material group [MATKL] in MDG system to provide data to train DAR machine learning model.

The CDS view Z_I_MATDAR is assigned as training dataset in the model

Input:

Output:

The intelligent scenario could be published after all the above steps are done.

Maintain connection mapping between intelligent scenario and DAR service (BTP) using service key and oAuth profile through the transaction ISLM_CONN_MAP.

 

 

 

 

In the Intelligent scenario management App, the model needs to be trained as well as deployed.

3. Master Data Governance (MDG)

MDG derivation BADI could be used to call the DAR which is configured in ISLM in MDG change request. In the BADI, it will derive material group using DAR from ISLM based on material type in the MDG CR.

Execution

Enter material type in the MDG change request which will derive material group based on AI-DAR service using ISLM.

Conclusion

In this blog post, we have learnt how to derive attributes in the MDG change request using AI business service - Data Attribute Recommendation (DAR) via ISLM.

entry.title: How to turn SAP workshop notes into clear and testable Requirements
entry.content:
During SAP Activate‚Äôs Explore phase and the Fit-to-Standard workshops, consultants capture dozens of ‚Äúrequirements,‚Äù each meant to articulate a specific business need. Without clear formulation standards, a few weeks later no one is quite sure what the original request actually meant. This undermines the workshop‚Äôs primary goal: validating solution fit.

The real pain - inconsistency

In SAP programs, requirements that are vague or inconsistently written become a main source of unnecessarily lost effort. When two workstreams describe the same business need in different words, duplication multiply which may lead to unnecessary testing of the same functionality or cause change requests.

For example, when a requirement says ‚Äúsystem should support automatic approval‚Äù no one will know what support actually meant when they discussed it during a workshop. You cannot test such a requirement later.

Ambiguity has measurable cost

Each unclear requirement multiplies into unnecessary discussions, rework, and test defects. Misunderstandings accumulate silently until they become visible during the first cycle of testing, when the system finally reveals whether the requirement was truly met.

The true risk of Requirements Management is not the absence of requirements documentation, but the lack of consistency in how requirements are formulated.

Not having the requirement formulation standards, which are recommended by SAP Activate, is one of the major sources of rework and wasted effort. When requirements are written in different formats and tones, they cannot be easily classified, compared, or reused.

Why clear formulation matters

SAP Activate‚Äôs agile approach is built on the idea that requirements evolve. But they must be clear right from the start as the backlog entry, so that they can be reviewed, classified, and approved later. Clarity does not mean rigidity. It means writing requirements so they can be discussed, prioritized, tested, and traced - even as they may change later.

 A well formulated requirement contains four elements in one short sentence:

Who ‚Äì the role that needs the functionality
When ‚Äì the situation or trigger
What ‚Äì the action or system behavior
Why ‚Äì the intended business benefit

When these four parts are present, the requirement becomes verifiable. It can be confirmed during testing and explained during audit reviews. More importantly, it can be reused across teams and releases because it is self-contained and unambiguous.

The right format for SAP projects

SAP‚Äôs Agile method proposes the familiar User Story format: ‚ÄúAs a [role], I want [feature], so that [business value].‚Äù In practice, this structure is often too generic for configuration and testing.

A better pattern for SAP requirements adds context and system behavior:

As [Role], when [Condition], the system will [Action] on [Object] so that [Benefit].

This sentence looks simple, but it solves three common problems:

1) It describes the trigger (when), which links to a real process step.
2) It defines the system reaction (will [Action]), which makes the behavior testable.
3) It keeps the business benefit explicit, which ties it back to value and approval.

This version includes all four elements: who, when, what, and why.
Anyone reading it should understands both the intent and the expected outcome.

Adding a ‚ÄúHow to Demo‚Äù section

A practical way to make requirements even clearer is to include a short ‚ÄúHow to Demo‚Äù note directly under the description. This is not a full test case but rather a quick outline of how someone would prove that the requirement works. This serves as a draft for formal test cases and ensures that requirements can be verified during Activate‚Äôs test preparation phase.

This small ‚ÄúHow to demo‚Äù section acts as an early test-case draft. It helps reviewers visualize expected behavior and gives testers a ready starting point for building the formal Test Case later. In larger projects, these demo notes become a lightweight bridge between requirement authoring and structured testing, keeping intent, behavior, and verification tightly connected.

Finding the right level of detail

A well-written requirement should guide the Realize phase. Too much detail turns it into a mini-functional specification; too little makes it meaningless. The right level of abstraction sits between business intention and technical configuration.

When many team members are involved in requirements formulation, duplication can easily occur. Similar needs appear in different modules, often under different wording. To prevent this, each requirement should reference its related SAP Best Practice Process represented by an approved Scope Item. This simple linking helps identify overlaps early and supports reuse across workstreams.

From quick notes to refined requirements

In line with SAP Activate‚Äôs iterative principle, requirements may first be recorded in simple terms and refined later during backlog reviews and work package definition. What matters most in that moment is to capture the intent in a simplified form and then refine it later.

For example:
‚ÄúAdd a process step for automatic credit check approval before delivery creation.‚Äù ‚Üí GAP

Such a note still has value. During later review, typically when preparing the related Work Package, the requirement can be reformulated to the full standard:

As a Sales Manager, when a sales order is saved and the customer exceeds the credit limit, the system will block delivery creation on the delivery document so that only approved orders can ship.

This two-step approach keeps workshops efficient while ensuring that every requirement ultimately meets the agreed structure before review, approval, and test preparation.

How to make this standard work in Jira?

Formulation discipline is easier to maintain when supported by a tool.
In Jira, you can create an automation rule that pre-populates the Description field of each new Requirement with a Activate-style structured template.

In the template, you can use a table to make the content easier to follow. Each author then only needs to fill in the blanks. This keeps every requirement standardized.

For simplicity, below the requirement you can add a simple list with the ‚ÄòHow to demo‚Äô steps.

Why it‚Äôs worth the effort?

A requirement is not a transcript of a workshop discussion. It is a helpful SAP governance standard that supports the SAP delivery lifecycle.

Teams that adopt this standardization rule quickly notice tangible benefits:
-> Requirements become easier to review and approve.
-> Test cases can be linked directly and generated faster.
-> Cross-team understanding improves, because every sentence follows the same logic.

Formulation discipline may feel like a big effort, but it pays back throughout the project lifecycle. Clear requirements accelerate testing, improve governance, and reduce rework.

If you have found this article informative, please leave me a Kudo on top of this page.
This will encourage me to write more articles in SAP Community. Thank you!

entry.title: SAP Universal ID Update: New Authentication Strategy and Self-Service Features
entry.content:
Users will no longer authenticate using their SAP Universal ID. Instead, the SAP Universal ID will function solely as a "wallet", enabling users to link and manage all their user identities in the‚ÄØSAP Universal ID Account Manager. Authentication will be handled through these linked accounts, not the SAP Universal ID itself. These broader identity renovation strategy advancements underscore SAP‚Äôs commitment to simplifying the user experience across its platforms by creating a more unified, secure, and user-friendly login experience across the SAP ecosystem in the future. 

 Self-service for identity Management to make changes to how will use the SAP Universal ID in the future and how it will authenticate with SAP's digital platforms  

 The SAP Universal ID Account Manager is a centralized portal where individuals can manage their unique personal SAP identity (Universal ID). It allows users to view and update personal details, manage security settings, link and consolidate various SAP user IDs (like S-user, P-user IDs), and retain their SAP community reputation and learning certificates across different employment changes. It acts as a single point of access to manage all SAP-related information and services in one place. 

 

https://account.sap.com/sam/ 

 

 

 

 

 New Features 

 Self-service for Identity Unlinking 

Users will be able to unlink specific users or email addresses with multiple users for the SAP Universal ID using the new self-service in the application 

 

Improved Flow for Adding New Identities 

The process for adding new Identity (previously called Add Accounts) has been streamlined: 

  • If an email already exists in the system, it automatically links it to SAP Universal ID (eliminating a previous manual linking step) 
  • If no user exists for that email ‚Äì the user is prompted to set up a password and a new P-user is automatically created in Identity Services. New identity is automatically linked to SAP Universal ID. 

 

 

Recovery Identity Prompt and Notification 

In case there is an email that was previously added to SAP Universal ID but there is no P/S-user ID associated with that email, the customer is prompted to make a choice ‚Äì either remove that email from SAP Universal ID or create a recovery identity that can be used for authentication across applications 

If ‚ÄúAdd Identity‚Äù option is selected, the customer is asked to enter a password, and a P-user is automatically created in IDS. New identity is automatically linked to SAP Universal ID. 

 

 

 In case there is only one email linked to SAP Universal ID; a notification is displayed reminding users of the benefits of having a recovery identity 

 

Removal of Mandatory SAP Universal ID Registration for New S-user IDs 

It is no longer mandatory to create an SAP Universal ID for a new S-user ID. Customers can decide if they want to link the S-user ID to an SAP Universal ID or keep the user on its own. This is a step in preparation to the new authentication strategy to be implemented later this year. 

 

 

Thanks for reading!‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
 
 
We would love to hear from you, let us know what you think?‚ÄØ 

If you have any questions,‚ÄØplease‚ÄØfeel free to‚ÄØask‚ÄØus in the Q&A‚ÄØAll Questions in Customer Experience | SAP Community‚ÄØand‚ÄØAll Questions in Support Services | SAP Community‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ Read more #Customer Interaction Centre‚ÄØblog posts‚ÄØHere!‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

Customer Experience - SAP Community  

Official SAP Community. Search questions and answers, read the latest blog posts and curated content, connect with experts, and improve your SAP skills.

entry.title: Re: Product Direction and Evolution of the New Table Build Experience
entry.content:
@JefB Hi. You're correct.

Story view time is compatible with only one table version at a time, so a combination of old and new table versions won't display correctly. You were using two table versions, leading to the issue I presume. When you align the table version to use the new one in both composite and story, the problem disappears.
Regarding the help documentation for wave 2025.21: we're going to fix it.

entry.title: Re: RAP cross-BO - enrich root BO obj. page create w. cross-BO info (readonly)
entry.content: Yes, this scenario is valid. However, in RAP, cross-BO association fields displayed via with cross associations; are always editable during creation unless they are explicitly defined as read-only in your projection or UI annotation. Since these fields are not part of your Order entity, you can‚Äôt set read-only behavior directly there. The standard approach is to expose them as calculated fields in the projection (via a determination or virtual element) and mark them with @ui.readOnly: true. This way, the Customer data is fetched dynamically and displayed as non-editable during Order creation.

entry.title: Re: Construction in Progress (CIP) Process using WBS in S...
entry.content:
Hello @byd 

Thank you for your question.

The following references will provide you with more details.

Recommendations in Capital-Investment Projects, Project Control - Enterprise Projects

Assets Under Construction: Management and Settlement, Journal Entry Tracing for Settlement

Period-End Closing in Projects

To summarise, your understanding is correct that the investment Internal Orders are not available in public cloud due to the clean-core principle. The standard approach for Construction in Progress is through Investment Projects manage by WBS elements, which act as the settlement receivers and senders for CIP and Asset Under Construction posting.

To your question on scope item, check out : Prerequisites &  Set Up SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with Procurement Expansion Package

To your best practice question, yes, it exists. Check out: https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2508.500/en-US/FSD_CE2508.pdf

Best is to use the Signavio Process Navigator to access full process flows, configuration guidance and implementation accelerators.

 

Consider following this clean-core approach:

Search for Enterprise Projects --> Choose as described (screenshots uses dummy details)

Create a WBS Project -->  Assign your WBS in the project field. Cost will be posted directly in WBS.

Go to Post Journal Entries ‚Äì Enter required details

-->  Expand line items -->  enter WBS element (choose your project number) in Accounting Assignment.

Credit line item 2 -->  enter details. Just offset done here. Your total Balance should be 0.00

Simulate -->  system confirms debit to expense and credit bank with WBS element

After posting -->  Go to Display Line Items in General Ledger -->  Enter your G/L Account and date.

Next go to your Project -->  click on tab Control -->  Click Create --> Fill the fields and save -->  Then Release or Save Project. Ensure to verify rule.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Administration of Collar FX Option (Product Type 76A)
entry.content:
Hello, experts,

I am trying to create a Collar FX Option in SAP S/4HANA using product type 76A. I have followed all the steps described in the SAP Help, which provides detailed guidance for creating this type of transaction.

During the process, everything seems consistent ‚Äî the values, dates, and configurations are correct. However, the SAP Help itself includes the following note:

‚ÄúWhen you conclude a transaction, the cash flow consists only of the premium. You can create both European and American types of option in the system (settlement).‚Äù

In other words, after creating the transaction, only the premium is generated in the cash flow.

However, in our actual setup with the partner bank, the following occurs: on the trade date, both the Put purchase premium and the Call sale premium are settled, resulting in a net zero value.

Therefore, my question is:
Is it possible to configure the Collar FX Option so that the premiums (Put and Call) are posted to treasury team on the trade date, resulting in a net zero cash flow, while still keeping the possibility to exercise one of the options on the settlement date, which should then trigger the corresponding premium posting upon exercise?

In addition, I would like to confirm:
At the settlement date, if I decide to exercise one of the options, which of the Functions available for processing FX options should be used to correctly close the transaction that will not be exercised?

Thank you in advance for any guidance or practical examples that can help clarify this behavior.

entry.title: Re: SAC NavigationUtils.openApplication or NavigationUtil...
entry.content:
Hi @Alex_B 

Alright, did some digging... 

1. Analytical Applications (Analytics Designer) is being phased out, in favor of optimized story designer, so I wouldn't use openApplication() API anymore, (although it seems to work for me behind a button script but it fails in onInit() script)

2. using openStory() API it can work like this
It's only hard to find and control the right story pageid...

NavigationUtils.openStory(mystoryid, mystorypageid,[UrlParameter.create("mode","embed"),
UrlParameter.create("pageBar","disable")],true);

3. using createStoryUrl() + openUrl() API it can work like this
still you need the story pageid

var url = NavigationUtils.createStoryUrl(mystoryid, mystorypageid,[UrlParameter.create("mode","embed"),UrlParameter.create("pageBar","disable")]);
NavigationUtils.openUrl(url,true);

4. using openurl() directly it is important if you use the "app.html" in your hyperlink, then you must use shellMode=embed in the right place like this

NavigationUtils.openUrl(mybaseurl+"/sap/fpa/ui/tenants/"+mytenantid+"/app.html#/story2?shellMode=embed&/s2/"+mystoryid+"?&pageBar=disable",true);

//or simplified (without need for baseurl & tenantid)
NavigationUtils.openUrl("/sap/fpa/ui/app.html#/story2?shellMode=embed&/s2/"+mystoryid+"?&pageBar=disable",true);

5 If using openurl() without "app.html", using the bo/story directory, you must use mode=embed, it is possible like this:

NavigationUtils.openUrl("/sap/fpa/ui/bo/story/"+mystoryid+"?mode=embed&pageBar=disable",true);

I would recommend this last option!
It seems a more future proof direct link, unrelated to "classic/optimized/enhanced/unified" story type, and not bound to a tenant or pageid.
Let me know if it works.

entry.title: Outbound Integration from SAP BTP, ABAP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud via Service Consumption Model
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog post will describe the Service Consumption Model for OData. I will describe its benefits, provide a description of the model, take a look at the OData Client Proxy at runtime and also dive into the ABAP cross trace integration as well.

If you want to receive or send data to an OData V2 or V4 service within SAP BTP, ABAP Environment or SAP S/4HANA ABAP Environment, you can use the "Service Consumption Model" for OData. As of release 2311, it is possible to consume Complex Types, Complex Collection, Action (bound) and Functions (bound). Of course, the consumption of Entity Types and Entity Sets is also possible.

Use case

If you have an SAP BTP, ABAP Environment or SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment system you can use the Service Consumption Model for OData. From here you can connect to a Cloud or an on-premises system.

In my scenario I am consuming the API - API_WAREHOUSE_ORDER_TASK_2 from another Cloud system. A call to the Entity Set Warehouse Task returns the following data:

Service Consumption Model for OData

Select File -->  New --> Service Consumption Model and choose OData as Consumption mode in ADT.

The consumption system requires a representation of the remote service. This knowledge is used to create the URL, write and read the JSON form the HTTP requests and responses. Therefore, the wizard needs the EDMX file (a service metadata document that describes the data model exposed by the service as an HTTP endpoint). OData uses EDMX as the format for this description of the remote service. You can get this by adding $metadata to the end of the service document, in my case it is the following URL - 

GET /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/$metadata

Save this file locally to use it in the below shown wizard. In addition, chose the appropriate class name. This class is the model representation and will contain all the types.

Finally, we get the Service Consumption model for OData. Create an outbound service object using wizard, which models the outbound call that will be implemented. The outbound service will be part of a custom communication scenario.

Create a communication scenario and assign the outbound service to it. This will be the basis for the outbound communication arrangement, which will be configured by an administrator at a later point. Keep in mind that the developer defines which authentication methods are supported, while the administrator decides which authentication method is ultimately used at runtime.

Consuming an Odata Service via Service Consumption Model

You can use the generated code snippet of the SRVC in and ABAP class, pass the name of the communication scenario and if required, the name of the communication system and the outbound service to CREATE_BY_COMM_ARRANGEMENT method, and perform the service call.

The following code is generated by the SRVC for the create operation of the OData service Warehouse Task.

Support for Actions and Functions

To call an OData action or function, the necessary structures and tables for the parameters are generated in the Service Consumption Model. With the 2311 release, however, the ADT (ABAP Development Tools) integration for OData V4 actions is still missing.

Consequently, I cannot yet select a bound action, an action import, a bound function, or a function import and directly generate the code snippet using the ADT tool. Despite this missing feature, the required parameter structure is available, and I can use it at runtime to call the operation.

üõ†Ô∏è Code Example: CancelWarehouseTask Action

Let's look at how to perform the CancelWarehouseTask action. Before implementing this using the Service Consumption Model, we'll verify the steps using the SAP Gateway Client.

For any standard SAP API, you should always consult the SAP API Business Hub to determine the correct syntax, required URL, and mandatory parameters for any action or function. The sample link confirms that the following details are required to execute this action:

  • Key Parameters:
    • Warehouse Number (EWMWarehouse)
    • Warehouse Task Number (WarehouseTask)
    • Warehouse Task Item Number (WarehouseTaskItem)
  • Concurrency Control: The ETag value is also required for conditional updates/actions.

The full API request URL for the action is:

POST /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/WarehouseTask(EWMWarehouse='{EWMWarehouse}',WarehouseTask='{WarehouseTask}',WarehouseTaskItem='{WarehouseTaskItem}')/SAP__self.CancelWarehouseTask?sap-client=<client>

‚öôÔ∏è Steps to Prepare the Details using SAP Gateway Client

To successfully execute the action, you first need to retrieve the current ETag and key parameters for the warehouse task.

  1. Perform a GET Call to Retrieve the Task Details and ETag.

Execute a GET request to the WarehouseTask entity set using the relevant warehouse and order numbers to retrieve the task details.

/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/WarehouseOrder(EWMWarehouse='0880',WarehouseOrder='9748')/_WarehouseTask

The response payload will contain the Warehouse Number, Warehouse Task Number, Warehouse Task Item, and the @odata.etag property for the required task.

        2. Perform the POST Call for the Action.

Perform a POST request for the CancelWarehouseTask action using the details (parameters) obtained in the previous step. Crucially, you must also include the ETag value in the If-Match HTTP header.

Post /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/WarehouseTask(EWMWarehouse='{EWMWarehouse}',WarehouseTask='{WarehouseTask}',WarehouseTaskItem='{WarehouseTaskItem}')/SAP__self.CancelWarehouseTask

Required Header - If-Match: W/"<ETag_Value_From_Step_1>"

üíª 1. Retrieving ETag and Key Parameters via Service Consumption Model

The first step is to read the entity to obtain its current ETag and key properties, which are required for the subsequent action call.

TRY.
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 1. Create HTTP Client and Client Proxy
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " Create HTTP destination using Communication Arrangement details
    DATA(lo_destination) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement(
        comm_scenario  = lv_commscetask
        comm_system_id = lv_commsystem
        service_id     = lv_serviceid_task ).

    lo_http_client  = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_destination ).
    
    " Create the OData V4 client proxy
    lo_client_proxy = /iwbep/cl_cp_factory_remote=>create_v4_remote_proxy(
        EXPORTING
            is_proxy_model_key       = VALUE #( repository_id       = lv_repid
                                                  proxy_model_id      = lv_proxymodelid
                                                  proxy_model_version = lv_proxymodlever )
            io_http_client             = lo_http_client
            iv_relative_service_root   = lv_servicerootwh ).

    ASSERT lo_http_client IS BOUND.
    
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 2. Navigate to the Resource and Read Data (GET)
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " Create a request for the read operation on the WAREHOUSE_TASK entity set
    lo_request = lo_client_proxy->create_resource_for_entity_set( 'WAREHOUSE_TASK' )->create_request_for_read( ).
    
    " Apply filter condition for the Warehouse Task
    lo_filter_factory = lo_request->create_filter_factory( ).
    CLEAR lt_range_warehousetask.
    
    " Populate range table (assuming <ls_keys> holds the task number)
    lt_range_warehousetask =  VALUE #( ( sign  = 'I' option = 'EQ' low    = <ls_keys>-warehousetask ) ).
    
    " Create filter node by range on the WAREHOUSE_TASK property
    lo_filter_node_1 = lo_filter_factory->create_by_range( iv_property_path = 'WAREHOUSE_TASK'
                                                          it_range         = lt_range_warehousetask ).
                                                          
    lo_request->set_filter( lo_filter_node_1 ).
    
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 3. Execute Request and Process Response
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    lo_response = lo_request->execute( ).
    
    " Retrieve the business data (ETag is implicitly available in the internal structure)
    lo_response->get_business_data( IMPORTING et_business_data = lt_business_data ).

CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lo_err).
    DATA(lv_text) = lo_err->get_text( ).
    
    " Error handling and logging (omitted for brevity, based on your original code)
    APPEND VALUE #( warehousetask = <ls_keys>-warehousetask
                    %msg          = new_message( ... v2       = lv_text )
                  ) TO reported-zn5_dl_c_createmon_task.
    APPEND VALUE #( warehousetask = <ls_keys>-warehousetask ) TO failed-zn5_dl_c_createmon_task.
    lv_flag = abap_true.
ENDTRY.

" -----------------------------------------------------------
" 4. Extract ETag from Read Results
" -----------------------------------------------------------
" Assuming you are looping through tasks, the loop structure is missing, but extracting the ETag is done here:
READ TABLE lt_business_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_business_data>) WITH KEY warehouse_task = ls_task-warehousetask.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
    " The etag field is automatically mapped in the generated structure
    ls_task-etag = <ls_business_data>-etag.
ENDIF.

IF lv_flag = abap_false.
    APPEND ls_task TO lt_task.
    CLEAR ls_task.
ENDIF.

üöÄ 2. Performing the CancelWarehouseTask Action

As previously noted, as of the 2311 release, the ADT integration for generating code snippets for OData V4 actions is still pending. Therefore, we must implement the action call manually.

Key Implementation Details:

  1. Bound Action Method: The method that triggers the bound action in the Service Consumption Model is typically named bound_action('ACTION_NAME') on the resource object. Here, the action name must be passed as a string literal: 'CANCEL_WAREHOUSE_TASK'.

          2. Concurrency Control: Since CancelWarehouseTask is a state-changing operation, it requires the ETag for optimistic locking. This is set using the set_if_match( etag_value ) method on the request object.

TRY.
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 1. Create HTTP Client and Client Proxy (using a different variable set, e.g., lo_client_proxy1)
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    DATA(lo_destination1) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement(
        comm_scenario  = lv_commscetask
        comm_system_id = lv_commsystem
        service_id     = lv_serviceid_task ).

    lo_http_client1  = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_destination1 ).
    
    lo_client_proxy1 = /iwbep/cl_cp_factory_remote=>create_v4_remote_proxy(
        EXPORTING
            is_proxy_model_key       = VALUE #( repository_id       = lv_repid
                                                  proxy_model_id      = lv_proxymodelid
                                                  proxy_model_version = lv_proxymodlever )
            io_http_client             = lo_http_client1
            iv_relative_service_root   = lv_servicerootwh ).
            
    ASSERT lo_http_client1 IS BOUND.

    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 2. Navigate to Entity and Bind Action
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " Construct the key for the specific WAREHOUSE_TASK entity
    DATA(ls_entity_key1) = VALUE #(
        ewmwarehouse        = lv_ewmwarehouse
        warehouse_task      = <ls_task>-warehousetask
        warehouse_task_item = '0' " Assuming the item is '0' for the action context
    ).
    
    " Navigate to the specific entity instance using its key
    DATA(lo_entity1) = lo_client_proxy1->create_resource_for_entity_set( 'WAREHOUSE_TASK'
    )->navigate_with_key( ls_entity_key1 ).
    
    " Bind the CANCEL_WAREHOUSE_TASK action to the entity resource
    DATA(lo_resource1) = lo_entity1->bind_action( 'CANCEL_WAREHOUSE_TASK' ).
    
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    " 3. Create Request, Set ETag, and Execute
    " -----------------------------------------------------------
    DATA(lo_request1) = lo_resource1->create_request( ).
    
    " Set the ETag (If-Match header) using the ETag retrieved in step 1
    lo_request1->set_if_match( <ls_task>-etag ).
    
    " Execute the action (POST request)
    DATA(lo_response1) = lo_request1->execute( ).
    
    " Action successful, continue with status handling...

CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lo_obj).
    DATA(lv_text) = lo_obj->get_text( ).

    " Error handling and logging (omitted for brevity, based on your original code)
    APPEND VALUE #( warehousetask = <ls_task>-warehousetask
                    %msg          = new_message( ... v2       = lv_text )
                  ) TO reported-zn5_dl_c_createmon_task.
    APPEND VALUE #( warehousetask = <ls_task>-warehousetask ) TO failed-zn5_dl_c_createmon_task.
    lv_flag = abap_true.
ENDTRY.

Conclusion: Seamless Outbound Integration with OData Service Consumption Model

This post demonstrated a complete, robust approach to Outbound Integration from the SAP BTP, ABAP Environment (or S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment) to an external OData API, specifically the API_WAREHOUSE_ORDER_TASK_2 in a cloud-to-cloud scenario.

entry.title: Re: VA02 - Screen overlap of "Partner tab"
entry.content:
I guess it's not an error from SAP GUI for Windows, but just in case download the latest SAP GUI version.

It could be a bug either in standard or custom code, because the selected tab and what's in the subscreen below the tabstrip could be desynchronized. Also possibly related to an error message sent on the screen at the same time (interrupting the process between switching from the Sales tab to the Partners tab). I see nothing in the SAP notes for VA02.

If there's a standard or custom bug, if you know how Dynpro works, you may check by yourself (debug > other tool > Dynpro stack, then watchpoint on the variables concerning the component ACTIVETAB of the tabstrip variable in CONTROLS variable TYPE TABSTRIP and the field containing the dynpro number as defined in the PBO statement CALL SUBSCREEN XXX INCLUDING dobj_for_program_name variable_dynpro).

Otherwise, contact SAP support.

entry.title: Building Bridges Between SAP and Databricks: A Dream Team for Your Data and AI-Powered Analytics
entry.content:
The Interplay of SAP & Databricks: Why Now?

The combination of SAP and Databricks is more than just a technical integration; it is a strategic course-setting. It brings together the best of two worlds:

  • SAP as a Stable Foundation: Your SAP systems contain the most important business data‚Äîfrom financial key figures to master data. This data is not only comprehensive but also semantic and contextual, making it an ideal basis for training AI models.
  • Databricks as an Innovation Engine: Databricks offers a scalable platform for Data, Analytics, and AI. It is a powerful engine for machine learning and complex analyses, enabling companies to gain valuable insights from large amounts of data.

This Dream Team transforms corporate management. Instead of merely answering questions like "What happened?", Business AI enables a look into the future: "Why did it happen?" and, most importantly, "What will happen and what should we do?".

Figure 1: Interplay of SAP & Databricks

 

The Benefits of Integration at a Glance

The partnership between SAP and Databricks offers tangible benefits that are evident at the strategic, technical, and operational levels.

Strategic Advantages

The integration ensures open data management and analytics for SAP and non-SAP data. Complete alignment with the SAP Business Data Cloud with strong governance creates a future-proof architecture. The simplified pricing model in general Capacity Units also makes the start easier to plan.

Technical Advantages

The platform is designed to allow extended use via interfaces and can scale with growing demands and data volumes. The seamless integration of the SAP Business Warehouse and SAP S/4HANA with data products enables an end-to-end process. An important difference when deciding for or against an SAP Databricks: The SAP Databricks is fully managed by SAP. This means it is technically operational immediately.

Operational Advantages

Companies benefit from a Hyperscaler infrastructure, which ensures resilience and a reduction in Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). Technical operation is supported by Managed Services from SAP, which reduces complexity in day-to-day business and allows for the installation of upgrades on demand.

How the Dream Team Works in Practice

Databricks offers a number of key elements to enable integration and analysis:

  • Unity Catalog: The Unity Catalog serves as a central landing zone for governance and data products. Metadata is managed here and the data is stored in Delta Tables, ensuring a consistent view of your information and secure access.

Figure 2: Databricks Unity Catalog: The landing zone for governance and data products.

  • Databricks Workspace: Modeling and development take place in the Databricks Workspace. Users work here with interactive notebooks, which offer an encapsulated programming interface for agile and flexible work. SQL, Python, R, and Scala are supported as languages.

Figure 3: Databricks Workspace: Modeling takes place in Databricks within the Workspace, using "Notebooks" among other tools.

  • Databricks Machine Learning: The integration of MLflow enables the training, versioning, and deployment of models. The clear management of training runs and the linking of datasets significantly simplifies the establishment of professional AI in the company. Important to know: The operation of Machine Learning models should strategically take place in SAP AI Core, although Databricks also supports this functionality depending on the use case.

Figure 4: Databricks Machine Learning. Model training (experiments), model versioning, or the deployment of models on one platform.

Conclusion: From Dataset to Smart Decision

The combination of SAP and Databricks elevates data analysis to a new level. Your financial key figures and master data serve as a reliable source for intelligent analyses. The integration with Databricks makes it possible to automatically recognize patterns and correlations from this data. The platform's flexibility and scalability allow complex AI models to be applied and the resulting cluster information seamlessly fed back into your SAP world to enable users to make well-founded decisions. The deep and exclusive technical integration of both worlds guarantees a secure and fast exchange of data products.

Key Takeaways for Your Company

  • Data and AI are moving closer together: The separation between data storage (SAP) and data analysis (Databricks) is a thing of the past. The seamless integration allows your most valuable business data to be used directly for modern AI applications. This creates a unified information base and eliminates fragmented data silos.
  • High Potential through Synergies: The combination of SAP‚Äôs standardized data storage and proven processes with Databricks‚Äô innovative AI technology opens up completely new possibilities. You can not only see what happened but also why it happened and what will happen next. This empowers you to act proactively and identify risks early on.
  • Professional AI Establishment: The Databricks platform offers a mature environment for professionally establishing AI applications in the company. Thanks to functions like Unity Catalog for data governance and Databricks Machine Learning for model training, you can ensure that your AI initiatives are scalable, secure, and sustainable.

How You Can Get Started Now: Our Practical Advice

Many companies hesitate to take the first step because the topic seems complex. However, getting started doesn't have to be overwhelming. We recommend starting with a Proof-of-Concept (PoC).

  • Define a Clear Use Case: Choose an area in your company where data analysis can bring real added value. This could be optimizing inventory management, predicting customer behavior, or automating financial forecasts.
  • Utilize Your Existing Potential: A PoC helps you assess how you can tap into your unused data potential. This provides concrete results and allows you to prove the business case for a broader implementation.
  • Start Small to Grow Big: Begin with a manageable project to achieve quick successes and build confidence in the new technology. The scalability of the platform allows you to easily add more use cases later.

The partnership between SAP and Databricks is not a futuristic concept but a practice-oriented solution that helps you make data-driven decisions and future-proof your company. The time to awaken your SAP data from its slumber is now.

Now it‚Äôs your turn: What experiences have you already had with using SAP data for intelligent analyses? What challenges do you see on the path to Business AI? We look forward to your perspectives and to shaping the future of data analysis together.
